column1: Knee pain is a common symptom in people of all ages.
If you have a history of arthritis, it could also cause knee pain.
A fluid-filled swelling behind the knee that may occur with swelling (inflammation) from other causes, like arthritis.

- Cancers that either spread to your bones or begin in the bones - Osgood-Schlatter disease - Infection in the bones of the knee - Infection in the knee joint Injuriesjoint Injuries and overuse - Bursitis.
Injury to the thick band that runs from your hip to the outside of your knee.
If your knee pain has just started and is not severe, you can: - Rest and avoid activities that cause pain.
- Take ibuprofen (Motrin) or naproxyn (Aleve) for pain and swelling.
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) can help relieve pain, but not swelling.
Follow these general tips to help relieve and prevent knee pain: - Always warm up before exercising and cool down after exercising.

Call your health care provider if: - You cannot bear weight on your knee - You have severe pain, even when not bearing weight - Your knee buckles, clicks, or locks - Your knee is deformed or misshapen - You have a fever, redness or warmth around the knee, or a lot of swelling - You have pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, or bluish discoloration in the calf below the sore knee - You still have pain after 3 days of home treatment
Your health care provider will perform a physical exam, and look at your knees, hips, legs, and other joints.

Your provider may do the following tests: - Joint fluid culture (fluid taken from the knee and examined under a microscope) - X-ray of the knee - MRI of the knee if a ligament or meniscus tear could be the cause - CT scan of the knee Your provider may inject a steroid into your knee to reduce pain and inflammation.
